summary: An email from defense attorney Christian Everdell to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, requesting weekend laptop access for Ghislaine Maxwell to review discovery materials, inquiring about missing hard drives, and renewing formal discovery requests. It highlights logistical challenges in Maxwell's defense preparation while she is in custody.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell writing to the U.S. Attorney's Office to request access to discovery materials and a laptop for his client.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused individual whose defense team is requesting weekend access to a laptop and discovery materials to review her case.

persons.name: Bobbi Stemheirn
persons.context: Copied on the email from the defense attorney regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

connections.description: Everdell is acting as Maxwell's defense attorney, advocating for her access to discovery materials.
Everdell is corresponding with Stemheirn, likely a prosecutor or legal staff, regarding discovery matters in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Previous Discovery Request
events.description: The defense team sent an email containing formal discovery requests to the prosecution.

events.title: Renewed Request for Laptop Access
events.description: Defense attorney Christian Everdell emails the U.S. Attorney's Office to request weekend laptop access for Ghislaine Maxwell and inquire about missing hard drives.

locations: 800 Third Avenue, New York, NY (Cohen & Gresser LLP office)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team reported that the prison computer could not read a substantial portion of the discovery materials on provided hard drives, hindering her case review.
The defense requested weekend access to a laptop for Maxwell, noting she had such access previously while in quarantine.
Maxwell had not yet received a 4TB hard drive with the complete discovery production or a smaller drive with materials originally on a CD.
The defense renewed specific discovery requests from a January 7, 2021 email, particularly seeking a list of 'Subject Devices'.
